intro: Nigritella nigra var. gallica, commonly known as the Gallic blackberry, is a variant of the blackberry plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It is characterized by its dark purple to black berries that ripen in late summer. The plant produces compound leaves with serrated edges and thorny stems, typical of the Rubus genus. Its flowers are small, white, and clustered in umbels, and it thrives in temperate climates with well-drained soil. This variety is valued for its rich flavor and is often cultivated for both culinary and ornamental purposes.
